content:
Hey guys, I've noticed that there are no Drafts link in the bottom of the message composer like in a regular Zulip. Is that intentionally?
Having drafts next to a composer is a good convenience, why to remove?

We are planning on adding more formatting buttons (#20302), and removed the drafts link to save horizontal space. Do folks miss having it in the compose box area, now that it's in the left sidebar?

I supposed we could put it to the right of "Help", now that we have that second line. We hadn't come up with that idea at the time that we removed it.
I don't miss it at all.
I think it's more discoverable next to the help link (or somewhere else in the compose box) but it's not a game-changer either way

I have definitely looked for it there, because in my mind I'm writing a message first, which happens to be a draft. So I open the message composer, realize there's nothing for me there, and make the trek all the way to the opposite corner of the window.

In short, I think "bottom of window" when writing a message, never "sidebar."
I do miss that.

Come on guys... I'm in compose box which I lost recently due to switching. I want to continue writing what I had. If there is no automatic recovery of my text in every compose box I do need Drafts link close to the compose box.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

I don't miss it at all.

(I also never minded it when it was there, to be clear.)
I too think it is helpful to have it near the compose box.
Ok, seems reasonable. @Aman Agrawal (amanagr) would you be up for adding the drafts link next to "Help"?

Vlad Korobov said:

Come on guys... I'm in compose box which I lost recently due to switching. I want to continue writing what I had. If there is no automatic recovery of my text in every compose box I do need Drafts link close to the compose box.

For reference, @Riken Shah (Riken-Shah) started work on automatically restoring drafts over the summer, but it's not complete (#18555).

And for context, automatically restoring drafts is one of those things that sounds simple but ends up being quite tricky just because naive algorithms are likely to have problems with duplicates, single-letter drafts, whether to pre-select the content of the draft when opening the composer (where typing a character deletes it all) or if not, where to place your cursor, etc. So it'll likely take a few rounds of iteration on chat.zulip.org before we'd have a version of that which feels like an actual improvement.

Alya Abbott said:

Ok, seems reasonable. Aman Agrawal (amanagr) would you be up for adding the drafts link next to "Help"?

This sounds like a good plan. We can hold off on deploying the new compose box to production until this is integrated.
Sure.
Opened #20707 (Got buried in my todo list for some reason, should have done yesterday.)
Screenshot-2022-01-07-at-12.16.58-PM.png
nice
How do folks feel about the visuals of this? It's been running on chat.zulip.org for a few days.

I think it's all right, but I somehow find the blue links a bit distracting in that area. It feels a bit busy while I'm finding the other buttons.

I personally rarely use the help button, and the draft button in the left sidebar works a lot better with my workflow than the compose box one. So for me it's just about how easy it is to click on the other buttons.

Screenshot-2022-01-12-at-8.08.31-AM.png

I don't know where to get those icons, but this looks better to me than our current state.
(From @Vlad Korobov 's design)
They look like Feather icons.
Yeah, thanks.
yes they are. I used them because you guys using them in mobile app already
We could just do a sweep to use nicer icons in the codebase.
well, they are customized by size too look good
so its not that easy
Oh, I see.
I'm not sure about the Drafts button should be blue. Grey looks ok, what do you think? image.png
I would say that blue looks like a link to me and would take me to a different page. We kept them blue to match with Subscribe to more streams and Invite more users at the bottom of sidebars.

Yeah, separately from the icon choices, perhaps we should move the "help" and "drafts" back into the row above, as in Vlad's screenshot. Making them the same color as the other icons seems reasonable to me.

How do folks feel about representing "help" with just the question mark icon, and having both the icon and the word for "drafts"?

I think it's nice for help to be really easy to find, but perhaps the question mark is standard enough.
Sounds good to me, we can even show the extended help text on wide screens and just the icon on narrow screens.

Aman Agrawal (amanagr) said:

Sounds good to me, we can even show the extended help text on wide screens and just the icon on narrow screens.

Mm, yeah, that could work. I think in that case we can hide both "Help" and "Drafts" text labels on narrow screens.

Using the writing icon for "drafts" conflicts with our using that icon for "stop doing preview mode":

image.png

But maybe that's OK in the long term in that we'd like to make preview into a toggle/tabs UI instead?
We could also consider leaving them where they are right now, but just changing them to use the same color as everything else rather than blue? Not sure if that'd look good.
I agree the blue really draws one's eyes to it in a way that is undesirable -- we want to make it easy for your attention to be on whatever you're writing when using the compose box.
Yes, my intention was to make an icon of preview which is all the way to the left make as toggle with pressed and unpressed status, similar to topbar users's list activation.
For background, the tabs idea Tim Abbott is referring to was discussed in #feedback > compose preview widget , but we never settled on a design.
Having just an pressed/unpressed eye-icon button could work.

Alya Abbott said:

Having just an pressed/unpressed eye-icon button could work.

Yeah, and I think that'd be a better design pattern than what we have today.
@Vlad Korobov what would that look like visually, if it's quick to illustrate?

Could we push to get the compose box buttons to a state where they can be deployed to Zulip Cloud? @Aman Agrawal (amanagr)

I seems like the next thing to try is probably:

  1. Move Help and Drafts to the right of the URL formatting button, and make them the same color as other buttons.
  2. Following Aman Agrawal (amanagr) 's suggestion, show both the icon and the text for help and drafts on wide screens, and drop the text (for both?) on narrow screens.

I think we can do this separately from changes to the preview button discussed above. The current pencil icon is already being used in the left sidebar on Zulip Cloud, so changing it would be user-facing whether we do it now or later.

Alya Abbott said:

Vlad Korobov what would that look like visually, if it's quick to illustrate?

I showed it here https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/101-design/topic/UI.20redesign.3A.20compose.20icons/near/1314570

Vlad Korobov said:

Alya Abbott said:

Vlad Korobov what would that look like visually, if it's quick to illustrate?

I showed it here https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/101-design/topic/UI.20redesign.3A.20compose.20icons/near/1314570

Cool, I spun that off to a separate thread (#design > preview icon ).

large
mid
small
Not having icons for Help and Drafts would be better, because that would make them more distinguishable
I actually think that we should put help icon as a third one next to ^X

image.png

I like them better with the icons. We would still need icons for smaller screen sizes (or move the text somewhere else to fit it).

icon for help is ok but should be in another place. I'm not sure icon for drafts is recognizable, but in my suggested design I do move it to the right top corner and for the smaller size I don't think we should bother to show it at all
image.png
It is a good option. What do folks like more?
Do we want font-size of Drafts to match send? (Alya pointed it out)
image.png

OK, here's a somewhat related question: should we use the keyboard icon rather than the ? icon in the compose box? That would make it consistent with the icons we use in the gear menu : ? -> help center, keyboard -> keyboard shortcuts menu.

Screen-Shot-2022-01-31-at-12.06.48-PM.png

Whichever icon it is, I would try putting it a bit further to the left, to leave some space between it and the two icons that are used for manipulating the compose box itself. Otherwise, the last screenshot looks OK to me.
I think help icon is the way to go here since we are providing help for compose box formatting.
image.png
image.png (Sorry if looks too bad, just trying to match size)

image.png

Center aligned top elements.
(Updated the PR too)
Without outline around Drafts is better

Aman Agrawal (amanagr) said:

I think help icon is the way to go here since we are providing help for compose box formatting.

Actually, the keyboard icon isn't quite right either, since this is the relevant part of the settings menu:

Screen-Shot-2022-02-01-at-9.00.16-AM.png

Thinking about it now, using a pencil there is not great -- it's the same icon we use for drafts. What if we change it to A or Aa, which is pretty standard for formatting, both in the menus and in the compose box?
(As a reminder, Google Cloud currently just has a "Help" link with no icon, so we're introducing a new symbol here.)
Aa could work, but I would be more inclined to click ? in compose box rather than Aa since I won't know what it will do until the first click.
We can do Aa Help for wide screens and Aa for small screens too if we want to go with this change.
(Oops, Google Cloud -> Zulip Cloud above. No idea why I typed that. :))
image.png

Peeking over my shoulder, Tim Abbott suggests putting Aa between the link button and the | on its right. It seems reasonable to me -- you use B/I/link for some types of formatting, and Aa tells you how to do the rest.
What is Aa?
It's a replacement icon for the ? (see discussion above).
I guess I need to see it to understand, sorry
If we talk about Icon for that menu image.png there is an edit icon in a rectangle I think...
https://fontawesome.com/v5.15/icons/edit?style=regular
That overlaps with our preview icon.
image.png
Well preview Icon will be replaced with a status highlight
but its not overlaps but relates
yes.. they are about the same thing, its not that bad
Ok ... there is Text icon https://fontawesome.com/v5.15/icons/text?style=solid
I guess by Aa you thought of that https://fontawesome.com/v5.15/icons/text-size?style=solid
image.png
We have to use icons in v4.7, https://fontawesome.com/v4.7/icons/, text-size is not available here.
(Above image needs alignment )
Makes sense to me to have it there.
So what is Aa in the compose box?
It is an icon which opens message formatting.
Ok, and what is question mark in the top right of the compose box?
Oh! sorry, we replace that question mark with Aa icon.
I think it's somewhat important to put the formatting icon fairly early in the tab sequence, so that keyboard users don't have to reach for the mouse to see it.
I'm confused, you call it formatting icon and you call it help and you place it inside other formatting buttons while it is a separate section where you can learn how to use some code, correct?
I think the icon to get help for formatting should be before every icon other than possibly preview and attach-file.
Why?
Doesn’t look like the first thing that user need, especially if we are going to have formatting buttons. Help is the last thing user needs when there is no clear way to make what he wants.
We should prioritize providing clear ways instead of “read the book” links

We want to be considerate of people who either can't use a mouse or choose not to use a mouse. If you are a keyboard-centric user, then it's helpful if the formatting help is easy to reach without tabbing past eight other icons.

I don't really consider our formatting-help to fall into the category of "read the book" links. We have very strong evidence that a non-trivial portion of our user population understands the basic concepts of markdown, and sometimes you just need to check the help to remember the exact syntax.
For mouse-centric users I would argue it's actually more convenient if the specific formatting icons like B and I are closer to the middle. So it might be a win-win.

Most users, of course, use both devices if they can. When you're in the compose box you are generally already at the keyboard, unless you are using some kind of dictation solution. So the compose-box experience should take that somewhat into account.

I think there is a plausible argument that my own usage patterns completely bias my decision-making here. I will concede that I am somewhat keyboard-centric and experienced with markdown. But I also use the mouse all the time and forget markdown idioms like any normal person. My brain may be different from the average person, but it's not that different from an average Zulip user.

If you are keyboard oriented, its ok to provide a hotkey for the action you are looking. But placing help as a first visual button works as bad waiter in a restaurant. Such waiter is asking you if everything is ok when you don’t need him and he is very slow in bringing whatever you ordered. I am a keyboard user and i do use help but its not an argument to place help above the all. I agree with this argument if we are talking about the terminal based interface.

I have spent a lot of time in restaurants, and the first thing that either the host or server gives you is the menu. This analogy is probably too strained to be useful, but I view formatting help as the menu.
It's hard to have a hotkey for formatting help when the user is already composing, but I suppose something like control-? would be plausible.

Hm, I don't think I see the argument for markdown help being more commonly used than other compose box icons. What does it document that folks actually use frequently, but will struggle to remember and need a reference for? I think Markdown URL syntax is sufficiently unintuitive that it might have been in that category, which is why I'm super excited that we added a button for them.

I think in general, you're either going to use something rarely (and then go look it up), or if you use it frequently, you'll memorize the syntax.
See my earlier point that tab order matters a lot for keyboard users and less so for mouse users. I am happy to clarify.
You can satisfy both types of customers.

Menu - should be just on a table, that is what we are going to do with icon buttons. If you need more - you expand like flipping a menu to see what are the dishes available and not only a lunch things. And only if you are confused by the choice you ask for help. Again I do support having a hotkey for showing any kind of help. I don’t suggest in this case to mess with a diff between tab order and the visual order of buttons
I agree that we should show tooltip info somehow to show you what is the hot key behind the button you are currently focusing on
To be clear I want the tab order to match the visual order of the buttons.
Ok, so help shouldn’t be a menu. Only in the case if its a single button and there is nothing else
The restaurant analogies are really strained. I have spent plenty of time in restaurants, and I have a good idea how they work. Likewise for chat. They are different animals.
I simply think we should put formatting help early in the tab order.
I have spent enough time in my life working at restaurants to even know some implementation details. :joy_cat:
I shouldn’t be a hypocrite. Let’s explore this analogy, it’s kinda fun.
Do restaurants have usability issues?

If I don’t have some food right away its not great (input field). If the menu has no pictures its less accessible (compose icons). I prefer experience when I don’t need to ask questions (i can see all compose icons) but if I do I wish them be addressed at the same moment ( help window is very near ).

What you are trying to sell me Steve is a nice waiter which can help me in the first place and I’m telling you that fast food menu with pictures is the way to serve people and all the questions can be addressed after that clear shining menu is in place
I am maybe telling you we are running a higher class restaurant?
Our target audience is almost axiomatically people who value text based communication. We are not Instagram.
Zulip’s target audience includes some of the smartest people in the world. We are not asking them to master Sanskrit, Icelandic, or jujitsu. It’s just markdown.

So would we address everyone's concerns by figuring out a hotkey to use for popping up Markdown cheatsheet from the compose box (err, a button to call the waiter)? And then it would free us up to put the button to access that cheatsheet wherever we want, without feeling limited by how easy/difficult it would be to tab to (err, the waiter wouldn't have to stand nearby because you have a magic button to call them over)?
yup control-?
I still think we are overestimating the learning curve for markdown for our users. Our users are not average people.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

yup control-?

I guess that shortcut currently opens up the Help Desktop app menu, or the Help browser menu if you're using the browser.
Hrm ok
I stand by premise that you can put formatting help earlier in the tab order sequence without negatively impacting newbies or mouse-centric users.
I dunno, I agree with Vlad Korobov 's perspective that it doesn't really belong on the left, so I'm much more excited about the shortcut direction. :)
Fair enough. I don’t have much to add.
I'm deploying the latest version of #20707 here so we can experience it.

Also, thanks to everyone for all the attention on this. I know it may feel like a ton of obsessing over these little details, but they are important, and as we've seen with all the discussion, there's actually a lot of tradeoff to think about carefully in these details.
